tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: Die Reise nach Damaskus 1888/89: Tagebuchaufzeichnungen des Orientmalers

Donnerstag, den 27. Dezember. Morgens warte ich bis 9.45 Uhr, als endlich Joseph daherwackelte. Ich ärgerte mich sehr darüber, weil es seit langer Zeit der erste klare Morgen war. Wir gingen zuerst zur Seitentüre der kleinen Moschee, wo ich zuerst vier Platten opferte und dann an der Aquarellstudie weiter arbeitete. Wie gerne hätte ich einen Phonographen bei mir gehabt, um die Töne, welche mich umschwirrten, festhalten zu können. Nachmittags nahm ich in der Amara zwei Photographien auf und machte dann noch fünf Bleistiftskizzen in den kleinen Seitengassen, in welchen die vielen Säulen in die Häuser eingemauert sind. Entweder gab es in Damaskus früher Säulenstraßen wie in Palmyra, oder es wurde der alte heidnische Tempel inmitten der Stadt von Säulenhallen ringsherum eingeschlossen.
NACP RG 84 Damascus Vol.10 Damascus, Mishāqa to Mektubci Bey 27 Feb. 1909
further reminder as to the provincial bonds hold by M, interest rates not paid

The numbers from the early 1880s contain 2 pages each in French and Arabic back to back that are not numbered. The news are replicated in the two languages only to a certain extend. The French version has more international and news from Constantinople without quoting extensively from Suriye or publishing regulations, laws, etc. as the Arabic version does. It is published weekly every Thursday in Beirut by Khalīl Efendi al-Khūrī, the director of foreign affairs of the province of Syria.
AUB holdings comprise copies between 1858-68 and 1881-88 (
Mic-NA:000147), StaBi holds copies between 1858-65
SOAS Main Library Ex Per 41753 Note: Lacks nos40,177,450,454 Holdings: n20 -n506, 1858-1868. Main Library M4938 Note: negative microfilm 4 reels. A Copy is held by FU Islamwissenschaft
Same at British Library (OP.401) and University Haifa.
Fruma Zachs 2009:630 claims "The issues from 1868 to 1881 and 1888 to 1911 have been lost, so we are unable to establish a clear pattern of the development of themes in this journal. "

tss:note.title: Art 1
tss:note.comment: Art 1: the law is concerned with the roads in the empire. the highest class are the roads from the provincial capitals to Istanbul. [apparently the law is only concerned with the roads outside of any settlement] $$road works$$ $$terminology$$ some other text

tss:note.title: Art 7: corvée labour in cities, towns, and villages
tss:note.comment: those in the age of manual labour (fī sinn al-aʿmāl) are liable to crovée for road works, they can either work themselves, pay an exemption fee, or provide beasts of burden

tss:note.title: Art 8
tss:note.comment: - liable inhabitants are established by census. everyone has to serve 20 days in five years or pay an exemption fee. - beasts of burden

tss:note.title: Art 9: extend of works
tss:note.comment: - a day's work is at least 9 pics of pavement (turāb) lining the sides of the streets, or 2,5 pics of road works (taking the stones and breaking them up and lying them on the street) - a day's work of a beast of burden is to transport the whole stones from the warehouse/ quarry to the construction site.

tss:note.title: Art 10
tss:note.comment: - certain people are exempt from the works: clergy, rabbis, teachers at schools (makātib wa madāris), soldiers and gendarmes under arms

tss:note.title: Art 11
tss:note.comment: - extend of works and scheduled dates are established annually by the council of the sancak

tss:note.title: Art 14
tss:note.comment: - at the end of five years every settlement has to prepare accounts of the days of corvéed labour actually worked. if it differs from the legally allotted number of days, the inhabitants (ahālī) have the right / duty to compensate the numbers during the next five years

tss:note.title: Art 15
tss:note.comment: - cities, towns, or villages cannot order road works at locations more than 12 hours' distance, but by special order from the Sublime Porte

Damascus Affairs: Egyptian Rule in Syria through the Eyes of an Anonymous Damascene Chronicler, 1831-1841 [edition, translation, commentary]

#Justification of re-edition (7)
- the authors are aware of this text having been published and edited before at least twice. at least one of the two manuscripts held at StaBi, which form the basis of their work, had been used for earlier editions. Yet, even in the case where they come to conclusions similar to those of Sabānū—as, for instance, that the (one) author must have been a clerk in Sherīf Pasha's service (14)—they make no reference to his work.
- Aḥmad Ghassān Sabānū re-edited the well-known manuscript held at Stabi (No. 9787 / MS Petermann 188), of which a microfilm copy is available at AUB. The book was published in Damascus in 1980.
- al-Khūrī Qusṭanṭīn Pasha al-Mukhallisī had published the first edition in the early 20th century.

tss:note.tss:title: The chronicle focuses on the following topics: the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The chronicle focuses on the following topics: the rebellion of the Damascenes against the Ottoman governor in 1831; the Egyptian government and its policies; the various rebellions against Egyptian rule, especially those in Palestine in 1834, in Hawran in 1837-39 and in Mount Lebanon in 1840; the Damascene blood libel case of 1840; and finally the end of Egyptian rule and the first effects of the Ottoman Tanzimat reforms in Damascus.

tss:note.tss:title: He agreed that they should try to bring ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: He agreed that they should try to bring about a peace agreement, so the monasteries and the notables (afandiyya)231 [of Jerusalem] sent messengers to the shaykhs suing for peace. They [the shaykhs] answered:

tss:note.tss:title: Christian notables: wujūh
tss:note.tss:quotation: Now the notables (wujuh) of the Christians have gathered in the house of Master Ibrahim Tannus

tss:note.tss:title: Muslim notables: afandiyya
tss:note.tss:quotation: When the Mütesellim saw this, he said to the Muslim notables (afandiyya): ‘What do you have to say?

tss:note.tss:title: aʿyān and afandiyya as members of a council
tss:note.tss:quotation: On the same Friday, a session of the Administrative Council (diwan hukm) was held as usual. They set up a Consultative Council (majlis mashwara) made up of the notables (aʿyan), gentlemen (afandiyya) and merchants (tujjar), and an Egyptian Christian called Yusuf ʿAyrut474 became the council’s chief clerk (mubashir kitabat al-diwan), while Khawaja Rufaʾil remained director of the treasury.

tss:note.tss:title: 1832 Price Rises and the Death of the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: 1832 Price Rises and the Death of the Zarbhane Emini

tss:note.tss:title: Those of them who were hoarding supplies of ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Those of them who were hoarding supplies of wheat began to squirm, for the Vizier announced that anyone who knew that someone was concealing wheat and informed the government would receive a reward (bakhshish) of 100 kuruş

tss:note.tss:title: A few days after the Vizier arrived, the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: A few days after the Vizier arrived, the price of a ratl of bread rose from 44 to 60 fidda, and one mudd of wheat which had cost 6 kuruş was priced at 8 kuruş, but could not be found [even at that price]. Thus all the Vizier’s speeches had no effect.

tss:note.tss:title: At the beginning of Lent (al-Sawm al-Kabir),106 the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: At the beginning of Lent (al-Sawm al-Kabir),106 the situation worsened. One mudd of wheat was sold in the city107 for 14 kuruş, one mudd of barley for 8 kuruş, maize for 10 kuruş, and a ratl of rice for 5 kuruş. Because the bakers in the market received only small quantities of flour, the situation at the bakeries was dreadful, and people waited half the day to get their bread. By the first Friday of Lent, things had become even worse. The people, stretched to the limit, snatched about 50 trays108 of bread in the streets and from the bakeries. They even stole dough in the streets, and from the knead-ing troughs inside the bakeries.

tss:note.tss:title: Coming back to the [issue of] bread, when ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Coming back to the [issue of] bread, when the authorities [lowered and] set the price of one ratl at 60 fidda, people waited to see what would happen. Within only a few days of their lowering the price, the bread [offered for sale] was as dark as liver104 and even then it as hardly available. By the end of January the price of [1 mudd of] wheat was 8 kuruş, but by the beginning of February, it had risen to 10 kuruş and more. One ratl of flour cost 3 kuruş and a loaf of white bread the size of a large biscuit (qataʾif) was 4 fidda, or 3½ kuruş for a ratl. A loaf of white oven bread (tannuri) was 8 fidda, or about 4½ kuruş for a ratl, and a ratl of brown rusks cost 4½ kuruş, too, as did a ratl of ‘military rice’ (al-ruzz al-ʿaskari),105 and other prices were at a similar level. This entire situation was due to the government’s inaction, while [real] au-thority remained in the hands of local leaders (awlad al-balad), who did whatever they wanted.

tss:note.tss:title: 1840: Ps 6 for a raṭl of bread
tss:note.tss:quotation: Some soldiers camped in the city’s artisan workshops and trading houses. Neither bread nor flour was to be found, because all the mills had been taken over by the government, as explained before, and the price of one ratl of bread reached 6 kuruş.

tss:note.tss:title: The anonymous Arabic chronicle that is presented here1 ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The anonymous Arabic chronicle that is presented here1 offers rich and de-tailed information about political and social transformations between 1831 and 1841 as experienced by a citizen of Damascus.

tss:note.tss:title: This edition and translation of the chronicle tries ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: This edition and translation of the chronicle tries to demonstrate that the text is not only a source of historical facts, but also an important document on the ways Arab inhabitants of the Levant in the 1830s and 40s thought and communicated about the social and political realities of their period. The value of the text is greatly enhanced by the fact that we have two ver-sions of it

tss:note.tss:title: Therefore we present the two versions in synop-tic ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Therefore we present the two versions in synop-tic form.

tss:note.tss:title: The English translation makes the chronicle ac-cessible to ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The English translation makes the chronicle ac-cessible to a wider readership with an interest in the history of the Middle East. For practical reasons, it follows MS Petermann 188, which is the more elaborate and better preserved of the two texts.

tss:note.tss:title: Translation
tss:note.tss:quotation: Translation

tss:note.tss:title: The present publication was initiated by the discovery ...
tss:note.tss:comment: At least the MS Petermann 188 has been edited before by Sabānū
tss:note.tss:quotation: The present publication was initiated by the discovery of an anonymous Arabic manuscript among the papers left upon his death by Johann Gott- fried Wetzstein, the first Prussian Consul assigned to the Ottoman Province of Damascus from 1849 to 1861.1 This discovery was made in the 1980s by Ingeborg Huhn as she prepared her doctoral dissertation based on the Wetzstein Papers, which are kept in the State Library of Berlin.2 As it even-tually became clear that the manuscript was a hitherto unknown recension of the Arabic chronicle known as Mudhakkirat Tarikhiyya or ‘Historical Memoirs’, which is also among the holdings of the Berlin State Library,3 we decided to publish a parallel edition of both texts together with an anno-tated English translation of the more elaborate version of the text (MS Pe-termann 188).

tss:note.tss:title: Previous editions
tss:note.tss:quotation: Given the importance of the events described in the text, it is not surprising that one of the two known recensions of this chronicle was edited as early as the 1920s by a Lebanese scholar, Qustantin al-Basha al-Mukhallisi,4 and that a second edition, by a Syrian scholar, Ghassan Sabanu, was published in 1980.5 Nevertheless, only relatively few historians of the period have used the text as a source,6 although many fields of study still might profit from it.

tss:note.tss:title: The title we have chosen for this book, ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The title we have chosen for this book, ‘Damascus Affairs’, attempts to capture the basic element of the text’s historical narrative: selected public events or ‘affairs’ (Ar. hawadith or maddat) that were discussed in the author’s hometown Damascus during the years 1831-41.

tss:note.tss:title: The four decades between 1830 and 1870, in ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The four decades between 1830 and 1870, in particular, can be regarded as a prolonged period of crisis, which reached its peak during anti-Christian riots in Mount Lebanon and Damascus in 1860.

tss:note.tss:title: Damascene politics was dominated by four political camps ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Damascene politics was dominated by four political camps that were identified with four areas of the city (see map 2):

tss:note.tss:title: 1) The citadel and the adjacent areas to the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The citadel and the adjacent areas to the north and west of it housed the political and military centres of power

tss:note.tss:title: 2) The residential areas around the government quarter were ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The residential areas around the government quarter were home to the loyalist ʿAzm

tss:note.tss:title: 3) The southern neighbourhoods, especially the suburb of Midan,25 ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The southern neighbourhoods, especially the suburb of Midan,25 were the stronghold of an oppositional faction, which was led by local militia leaders and by wealthy grain merchants.

tss:note.tss:title: 4) Finally, the Eastern part of the walled city ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Finally, the Eastern part of the walled city comprised the most impor-tant centres of the non-Muslim population

tss:note.tss:quotation: The Author and His Presumptive Public

tss:note.tss:title: in both versions the text is marked by ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: in both versions the text is marked by internal stylistic breaks which suggest that it was compiled from different sources.

tss:note.tss:title: 1831 Mehmed Selim Pasha Enters Damascus
tss:note.tss:quotation: 1831 Mehmed Selim Pasha Enters Damascus

tss:note.tss:title: Thus, we can locate the author - or ...
tss:note.tss:comment: This has already been noted by Sabānū, who should have been mentioned here
tss:note.tss:quotation: Thus, we can locate the author - or at least the author of this particular episode - in the scribal offices of the government building in Damascus. This also explains why the text quotes extensively from government documents and presents first-hand reports on the provincial administration.

tss:note.tss:title: Greek Orthodox
tss:note.tss:quotation: the author of the text belonged to the Greek Ortho-dox community, for he addresses the Greek Orthodox Patriarch residing in Damascus as ‘our lord the patriarch’36 and he sympathises with the Greek Orthodox in his description of quarrels between them and the Catholics in 1832.

tss:note.tss:title: textile industries / market
tss:note.tss:quotation: the author of these passages was well acquainted with the textile market and its social milieu.

tss:note.tss:title: partisan of the loyal-ist ʿAzm faction.
tss:note.tss:quotation: a partisan of the loyal-ist ʿAzm faction.

tss:note.tss:title: Finally, the author’s language shows him to be ...
tss:note.tss:comment: Sabānū 1980@7 did exactly that and claimed that the author had a recognisable Tripolitanian accent
tss:note.tss:quotation: Finally, the author’s language shows him to be a native of Syria, as he uses a number of terms and expressions typical for Levantine dialects, such as zalama (pl. zilim) for ‘man’ or ‘infantry soldier’, and siran for ‘trip’ or ‘out-ing’.40 It would be most interesting to see whether this dialect vocabulary is attributable to a specific town or region within Syria.

tss:note.tss:title: likely author: ʿAbdallah Nawfal from Tripoli
tss:note.tss:quotation: So it does indeed seem likely that the author was ʿAbdallah Nawfal, the father of the young Salim. At any rate, the passage indicates a close relationship with the Nawfal family.

tss:note.tss:title: The Lebanese historian ʿIsa Iskandar al-Maʾluf (1868-1956) has ...
tss:note.tss:comment: This again fits Sabānū's judgement, which they at least mention in the footnote
tss:note.tss:quotation: The Lebanese historian ʿIsa Iskandar al-Maʾluf (1868-1956) has advanced the thesis that the author of the chronicle was a native of Tripoli in Lebanon (Ta r a b u l u s a l - S h a m), ʿAbdallah ibn Jirjis Nawfal (1797-1866).

tss:note.tss:title: Nawfal Niʿmatallah Nawfal
tss:note.tss:quotation: The most prominent of them was ʿAbdallah Nawfal’s nephew, Nawfal Niʿmatallah Nawfal (1812-87), who spent his childhood years in Cairo and returned to Syria in 1828, where he served in several official positions and acquired some fame as an historian.

tss:note.tss:title: Our author was obviously not a professional scholar, ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Our author was obviously not a professional scholar, but one of many Syrian ‘commoner chroniclers’ who kept diaries and compiled historical re-ports during this period.51 Thus he does not cite any other writings as sec-ondary sources and concentrates exclusively on the period he himself wit-nessed. For whom, then, did he write? Considering the numerous blank lines and amendments in MS Petermann 188 (see fig. 1), one might take it for the unfinished autograph of a chronicle that had not yet circulated in public.52 However, the discovery of MS Wetzstein, a second version of the chronicle written by another hand, clearly demonstrates that the chronicle was copied several times and can thus be considered a published text.53 It seems probable that the text, especially the more concise and entertaining version in MS Wetzstein, was read out in front of a, mainly Christian, audi-ence in private gatherings or in coffeehouses.5

tss:note.tss:title: The Text: Contents and Structure
tss:note.tss:quotation: The Text: Contents and Structure
tss:note.tss:annotationDetails: {"Encoding":"V1","Selection Original Ending Point":"{227.019791,311.465546}","Type":"Highlighted Text","Original Selection Mode":"Text","Selection Target Zone":"{{54.989449,308.672500},{172.030342,14.077440}}","Rectangles":[{"Bounds":"{{53.320000,308.672500},{159.947584,14.077440}}","Corner Radius":3,"Fill RGBA":[0.3921569,0.627451,0.7843137,0.2]}],"Selection Original Starting Point":"{54.989448,314.792029}"}

tss:note.tss:title: The author’s own observations are mostly marked by ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The author’s own observations are mostly marked by phrases such as ‘you could see … (wa-tanzur)’.

tss:note.tss:title: Oral re-ports that the author received from other ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Oral re-ports that the author received from other people or overheard in conversa-tions in Damascus are introduced by phrases such as ‘it was said that… (wa-qila)’.

tss:note.tss:title: Excerpts from written communications, which the author may ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Excerpts from written communications, which the author may have accessed through his work in the government offices, are mostly introduced by phrases such as ‘a report arrived … and this is a copy of it (wa-hadhihi su-ratuhu)’.

tss:note.tss:title: The character of a montage - which is ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The character of a montage - which is not unique among Arab chronicles of the time74 - becomes clearer when one notes the logical and stylistic breaks in the text.

tss:note.tss:title: Like most contemporary works in this genre, the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Like most contemporary works in this genre, the chronicle is largely descrip-tive. However, in several passages, the author presents a brief causal analysis, and almost all these causes belong to four types.

tss:note.tss:title: meat and bread price
tss:note.tss:quotation: One okka of meat cost 20 fidda and one ratl of bread was sold for 1 kuruş and 4 fidda, and other prices rose in the same way. People became agitated and wanted the Vizier to arrive so that the situation would ease and prices come down.

tss:note.tss:title: in direct contrast to agents of disorder: the ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: in direct contrast to agents of disorder: the ‘locals’ who are driven by emotions and the desire for dominance, the un-disciplined Ottoman soldiery, the rebellious mountain peasantry and what the author calls the ‘foolish’ or ‘ignorant’ (al-juhhal) among the Christians

tss:note.tss:title: ʿarāḍa: celebrating, mocking Muslims
tss:note.tss:quotation: On the third day of the celebration, a group of foolish (juhhal) Christians gathered intending to stage a parade (ʿarada). When their own Christian no-tables (wujuh) forbade the parade, some of them turned to the Deputy Gov-ernor asking his permission to stage a parade, which he granted them. Thus they gathered and decorated a camel on top of which they seated Hamza al-Dhikra, a Muslim from the Kharab neighbourhood. They also put two bot-tles of arak147 on the camel’s back and carried two or three torches in the shape of crosses which they decorated with flowers and fruits. The proces-sion departed from Taliʿ al-Qubba with lines [of men] on either side, carry-ing wooden staffs. A crowd followed, also with sticks, some performing ac-robatic stunts, and others, led by a man with a baton, chanting rhymes like ‘Hail to the victorious Ibrahim Pasha! May God curse those who have been humiliated! (Ibrahim Pasha ya mansur, Allah yalʿan al-maqhur)’ and such like. The torches in the shape of crosses were carried amongst them and bringing up the rear was the decorated camel with the Muslim on its back. Whenever they advanced a few paces, he would take one of the bottles and wave it above the [on-looking] Muslims’ heads, shouting: ‘Christ is risen!’,148 while taking a swig [from the bottle].

tss:note.tss:title: muḥtasib, prices of foodstuffs
tss:note.tss:quotation: The Egyptians appointed a price inspector (muhtasib) by the name of Mustafa Agha Ibn Shubayb, who controlled all the prices, and no one could any longer exceed the [fixed] price by even one misriyya.

tss:note.tss:title: Most of the fools went around in parades, ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Most of the fools went around in parades, arak bottles in their hands, shouting in the streets of the city: ‘Pray to Jesus! Who can stand against us?! Our swords are drawn! The Lord is with us!’ And so they went on, non-stop, with songs and wearing their finery, for those three days, so that they made the Muslims very angry.

tss:note.tss:title: Then, Mehmed ʿAli Pasha sent a governor (vali) ...
tss:note.tss:comment: according to the index, the original would have used ʿarāḍa, but the source uses mawkib
tss:note.tss:quotation: Then, Mehmed ʿAli Pasha sent a governor (vali) to Damascus by the name of [Mehmed] Şerif Bey.168 He entered Damascus with a great parade, and the aʿyan came and welcomed him, among them Khawaja Hanna Bahri, who en-tered Damascus walking beside him.

tss:note.tss:title: 1839: Ps 18 for the kile of wheat
tss:note.tss:quotation: Wheat [for example] was sold from the threshing floor at 18 kuruş a kile
tss:note.tss:annotationDetails: {"Encoding":"V1","Selection Original Ending Point":"{382.650085,238.370865}","Type":"Highlighted Text","Original Selection Mode":"Text","Selection Target Zone":"{{56.536808,234.368652},{326.113281,11.843994}}","Rectangles":[{"Bounds":"{{53.320000,234.368652},{330.250732,11.843994}}","Corner Radius":3,"Fill RGBA":[0.9960784,0.8745098,0,0.2]}],"Selection Original Starting Point":"{56.536808,241.411621}"}

tss:note.tss:title: Parade (ʿarāḍa) of Christian fools
tss:note.tss:quotation: On the third day of the decorations, a Saturday, a group of foolish Chris-tians staged a parade, carrying sticks and dressed up, forming a parade, and singing songs. The procession went along with incense burners, perfume bottles and candles towards Bab Tuma, the Zaynabiyya, Mazz al-Qasab, ʿAmara, Surujiyya and the Saray, where they collected donations. Then they went on to Darwishiyya, Suq Jaqmaq,183 Khayyatin, Suq al-Silah, al-Buzuriyya, Maʾdhanat al-Shahm, and Taliʿ al-Qubba. That day, you could see the inhabitants of the whole city in the streets watching the scene, and the local people almost exploded with anger at what the Christians had done.

tss:note.tss:title: The text of our two manuscripts must have ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The text of our two manuscripts must have been compiled in the early 1840s, at a time of intense sectarian strife. In fact, the last events it reports concern the destruction of a church by angry Muslim crowds in a village close to Damascus.

tss:note.tss:title: index: ʿarāḍa
tss:note.tss:comment: Problem: these references combine mawkib and ʿarāḍa into one item

tss:note.tss:title: Mehmed Selīm Pasha, arrival at Damascus
tss:note.tss:quotation: a vizier2 by the name of Mehmed Selim Pasha3 entered Damascus amidst a great parade.

tss:note.tss:title: After a few days the Çorbacı arrived, and ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: After a few days the Çorbacı arrived, and the townspeople went out to welcome him and accompanied him into the city with a great parade.

tss:note.tss:title: The bodies of the Vizier and the other ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: The bodies of the Vizier and the other victims were taken and laid out in front of the gate of the citadel, naked, one by one, and people came to look at them from morning till evening that day. They also took the heads of the Vizier and his uncle and paraded them, firing guns and beating drums.

tss:note.tss:title: artisan strike: hunt strike breakers
tss:note.tss:quotation: The artisans went around [the city], [encouraging people] to revolt. When some of them arrived at the shop of ʿAsaʿisa, where they found an artisan at work, they wanted him to join the strike, but he refused. [Mean-while] the son of ʿAsaʿisa started to fight with one of the artisans and in-jured his hand.

tss:note.tss:title: [18 April 1838], an announcement concerning the official ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: [18 April 1838], an announcement concerning the official ex-change rates was issued.

tss:note.tss:title: provisions for the military
tss:note.tss:quotation: When the military camp was set up near the water in the centre of the Lajah, Ibrahim Pasha issued orders to the people of the Hawran that they should provide bread, 3 ratl for every feddan [of agricultural land in their possession]. [In addition], bread and rusk still came from Damascus.

tss:note.tss:title: opening of a winery
tss:note.tss:quotation: After that, an order was issued by Ibrahim Pasha that a [government] win-ery (khammara) should be established in Damascus, and he ordered the ad-ministrative council to make an announcement in the Christian and Jewish quarters and elsewhere so that the rights to it could be auctioned.185 The auction continued for fifteen days, and the licence was eventually sold for 700 purses (kis). The licence became valid on the Feast of the Cross and there were Christians, Jews and Muslims among the licensees. They took the Khan al-Masbana in the Kharab neighbourhood and the starch factory (Qaʿat al-Nashaʾ) and turned them over to wine production. The Muslims were visibly very downcast, because nothing like this had ever happened before in Damascus. One could see that the customers there were Muslims, Christians and Jews, and that arak and wine were openly served in coffee-houses and in the streets, including in ʿAli Ibn Munin’s coffeehouse, the Bab Sharqi Coffeehouse, the Bab Tuma Coffeehouse and stalls in Bab al-Jabiya, in the Horse Market, and in Bab al-Musalla.

tss:note.tss:title: alcohol trade, prices
tss:note.tss:quotation: A general order was issued to the effect that those who sold arak and wine or offered to sell arak and wine without a licence from the official wine producers would be subject to severe punishment (zayan).186 The authorities fixed the price of a ratl of arak at 12 kuruş and a ratl of wine at 6 kuruş.

tss:note.tss:title: People lined the streets, and a huge crowd ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: People lined the streets, and a huge crowd followed him, most of whom were not able even to catch a glimpse of him [because the street was too crowded].

tss:note.tss:title: There is a neighbourhood by the name of ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: There is a neighbourhood by the name of ʿAmara whose inhabitants are uneducated and wayward peasants and, because of their primitive understanding, they rioted for two hours. News of this reached the Vizier, and he immediately sent the soldiers to the city to kill, and rob and insult [them]. First the soldiers attacked a neighbourhood called Qanawat; they plundered it, abused its women and set fire to it. This was precisely the place where the salyane had been assessed first! He then sent an order to the citadel to shell the city with cannon and rifle fire. The soldiers were killing, plundering, burning and rob-bing, and those in the citadel shelled the city with cannon fire, intending to destroy it. The inhabitants of the city rose up to protect their honour and life.

tss:note.tss:title: rising bread prices
tss:note.tss:quotation: With regard to prices, [already] before the Vizier arrived, all the bread sellers had raised their prices, and wheat was no longer to be found.

tss:note.tss:title: 1832: bread riot of artisans
tss:note.tss:comment: began to raise the prices of their own produce
tss:note.tss:quotation: On the day when the price of bread reached 60 fidda, the local artisans rose up and demonstrated against the high cost of bread.1

tss:note.tss:title: Johann Gottfried Wetzstein (1815-1905)
tss:note.tss:quotation: Johann Gottfried Wetzstein (1815-1905)
tss:note.tss:annotationDetails: {"Encoding":"V1","Selection Original Ending Point":"{222.186707,203.150818}","Type":"Highlighted Text","Original Selection Mode":"Text","Selection Target Zone":"{{52.152637,204.367900},{170.034069,11.844000}}","Rectangles":[{"Bounds":"{{53.319700,204.367900},{166.625050,11.844000}}","Corner Radius":3,"Fill RGBA":[0.9647059,0.572549,0.2509804,0.2]}],"Selection Original Starting Point":"{52.152639,208.972661}"}

tss:note.tss:title: Egyptians sent a regiment of four thousand soldiers ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Egyptians sent a regiment of four thousand soldiers to meet him when he was about two hours away, and he entered the camp with a great parade. Mehmed ʿAli’s family88 welcomed him and had a marquee erected for him alongside them.

tss:note.tss:title: Khawāja, approximately ‘Mister’, honorific title for non-Muslim ...
tss:note.tss:quotation: Khawāja, approximately ‘Mister’, honorific title for non-Muslim dignitaries (see Yazbak 1998, passim).

tss:note.tss:title: 1) ahālī
tss:note.tss:quotation: Among them is the term ahali (here mostly translated as ‘the city’s local inhabitants’). Ahali was generally used as a neutral term for the population of a certain location, as in ‘the people of Damascus’. However, in the chronicle the term consistently refers to the Muslim population. Then there is a group designated as awlad al-balad (here: ‘the local towns-men’ or ‘the locals’). In the chronicle, this term mostly refers to members of the above-mentioned localist faction, who led the revolt of 1831. The author does not count himself and the Greek Orthodox among the ‘locals’.

tss:note.tss:title: 2) notables: Āğā, aʿyān, wujūh, and efendiyya
tss:note.tss:quotation: The principal political and military leaders of the Muslim majority population are the aghas or paramilitary chieftains, while the civil elites are referred to as ‘notables’ (aʿyan, wujuh, and in Muslim contexts also afandiyya). They act as political representatives of certain population groups, who negotiate with the Ottoman or Egyptian rulers. The Christian and Jewish communities have ‘notables’ of their own.

tss:note.tss:title: 3) artisans: ahālī al-ḥiraf
tss:note.tss:quotation: members of the artisans’ guilds (ahali al-hiraf)
tss:note.tss:annotationDetails: {"Encoding":"V1","Selection Original Ending Point":"{321.101685,305.315369}","Type":"Highlighted Text","Original Selection Mode":"Text","Selection Target Zone":"{{118.052170,302.527900},{203.049515,11.844000}}","Rectangles":[{"Bounds":"{{116.794449,302.527900},{205.802658,11.844000}}","Corner Radius":3,"Fill RGBA":[0.4392157,0.6431373,0.5372549,0.2]}],"Selection Original Starting Point":"{118.052170,307.146527}"}

tss:note.tss:title: 4) ‘honourable’ or ‘respectable people’
tss:note.tss:comment:
*ahl al-ʿirḍ*, also from different religious communities, people who do not take to the streets
$$terminology$$
tss:note.tss:quotation: ‘honourable’ or ‘respectable people’ (ahl al-ʿird or ashab al-ʿird).
tss:note.tss:annotationDetails: {"Encoding":"V1","Selection Original Ending Point":"{110.767876,294.682373}","Type":"Highlighted Text","Original Selection Mode":"Text","Selection Target Zone":"{{110.767876,289.507965},{265.840912,11.843994}}","Rectangles":[{"Bounds":"{{109.387772,289.507965},{269.692017,11.843994}}","Corner Radius":3,"Fill RGBA":[0.4392157,0.6431373,0.5372549,0.2]}],"Selection Original Starting Point":"{376.608795,295.635071}"}

tss:note.tss:title: ʿarāḍa
tss:note.tss:quotation: On the third day of the celebration, a group of foolish (juhhal) Christians gath-ered intending to stage a parade (ʿarada). When their own Christian notables (wujuh) forbade the parade, some of them turned to the Deputy Governor asking his permission to stage a parade, which he granted them. Thus they gathered and decorated a camel on top of which they seated Hamza al-Dhikra, a Muslim from the Kharab neighbourhood.

Contains mostly consular notes on salaries, expenses, conduct of duties sente:/BachBibliographie/Fo783423ConsulGeneral+1882 Draft Beirut No.9, 20 May 1882, to Eldridge John Dickson is appointed VC at Damascus and placed under Eldridge's supervision Beirut Consular 3, 3 January 1882, Eldridge to Granville inclosed list of persons acting as VC under within his district Beirut Consular 6, 28 January 1882, Eldridge to Granville forwarding Jago's application for prolonged leave of absence. No suitable personal at hand to replace him. Suggest sending a trainee to Beirut; Dickson could then go to Damascus Beirut COnsular 8, 28 March 1882, Eldridge to Granville confirming to have received the approval for Jago's leave of absence, which Jago proposed to beginn towards the end of April. Dickson will proceed to Damascus. Beirut Consular 9, 1 April 1882, Eldridge to Granville £85"13"6 salary to Dickson for last quarter £25 to the chief clerk Beirut Consular 13, 8 May 1882, Eldridge to Granville Jago left Damascus 4 May, Dickson proceeds there Beirut Consular 14, 25 May 1882, Eldridge to Granville reply to a confidential report that some positions of unpaid VC in Asian Turkey and Syria were achieved through bribery. Eldridge serves for 19 years in Syria and has files all the placements under his jurisdiction. If the British adopted the French system of appointing salaried nationals everything would be fine. But under the current system he has to pick the most suitable foreign resident who is willing to serve as VC. The gentlemen are the best to be found on the spot. Strict rules for employing Dragomans and Cavasses laid down in 1863: 4 each for independent consulats at main places of the province; 3 at dependent ones, and 2 each at VC. He stuck to the rule. On arrival he instructed the VCs to reduce the number of protégés and "deprived a large number of persons of British protection." The above mentioned report advised to allocate only 1 Dragoman and 1 Cavass to VCs, as this would relate to British VCs only, it is a grave step in diminishing the public image of Britain. Dragomans are local Ottoman subjects and unpaid as well, thus they are often absent with their own business and hence the necessity of 2 dragomans. A lengthy account of the duties and functions of the Beirut Consulate follows, finished with an account of the expenses for rent in comparison with Damascus: "while only £32 is paid for the larger Consular residence and office in Damascus". Then Haiffa, Sidon, Lattakia, Tripoli. BUt not Damascus Alich, 15 October 1882 Draft Damascus 1, 18 Mar 1882, Jago Expenses for official telegrams Draft Damascus 1, 29 May to Dickson information that the Queen has appointed him VC in Damascus £500 as salary, £200 allowances Draft Damascus 2, 19 May 1882, to Dickson again about his institution Draft Damascus 4, 27 June 1882, to Dickson Letter of support/introduction from the FO/Granvill for Mr. Tresco, the director of the Jewish School at Damascus Draft Damascus 5, 27 June 1882, to Dickson on the same issue, Dickson is recommended to visit the school from time to time and he should "do so whenever a convenient opportunity may occur" Damascus Consular 1, 2 January 1882, Jago to Granville £172"7"11 salary and allowances for last quarter Damascus Consular 2, 2 January 1882, Jago to Granville Return of births, and "nil" deaths and marriages for 1881 (enclosure not included) Damascus Consular 3, 2 January 1882, Jago to Granville expenses for telegrams £5"6"2 Damascus No.4, 20 January 1882, Jago to Granville 10 years absence from England and impaired health causing Jago to ask for prolonged leave of absence from his post, proposes late April as starting date. Last visit to England in 1872. Damascus Cons.5, 6, 31 March 1882, Jago to Granville telegrams, expenses Damascus Consular 7, 1 April 1882, Jago to Granville £172"7"11 salary and allowances for last quarter Damascus No.8, 4 May 1882, Jago to Granville He will leave Damascus tomorrow for England Damascus Consular 9, 12 May 1882, Dickson to Granville In compliance with given orders he proceeded to Damascus and took charge as acting VC Damascus COnsular 10, 29 May 1882, Dickson to Granville statement of the gross amount of all fees and remuneration received at the VC in Damascus for the year that ended 31 March 1882: £20"13"2 Damascus Consular 11, 30 May 1882, Dickson to Granville statement of expenses for his journey from Beirut on 10 May Damascus Consular 1, 17 June 1882, Dickson to Granville receipt of his appointment as VC Damascus Consular 4, 1 July 1882, Dickson to Granvill £115 as outfit, to the order of the Imperial Ottoman Bank Damascus Consular 5, 19 July 1882, Dickson to Granvill concerning the letter of introduction for Mr.Tresco/Fresco, and the visits to the Jewish School Damascus Consular 9, 19 October 1882, Dickson to Granville Spanish Consul asked Dickson to act for him during his absence. On the 12th this was granted by the Embassy in Constantinople. DIckson will be in charge from 2 November

"He was received at the station by the Chief of Police and the dragoman of the vilayet as representatives of the Vali, an officer representing the Mushir […], dragomans of the foreign consulates, a bishop priest and deacon representing the Greek Orthodox Patriarch, and lay representatives of the Greek Catholic, Greek Orthodox and other Christian communities besides several Greek Catholic bishops and priests." proceeded to church and then to the Patriarchate where the reception was attended by the acting French consul. Upon asking the Vali received communication from the Porte confirming the election of the Patriarchate.
FO 618/3 Damascus Draft 51, Quarterly Report, Devey to Lowther 1 Oct. 1908

[…]
"the great ‘coup d’Etat’ which took place in Turkey on the 24th July occupied all minds and arouses every emotion with the proclamation of the Constitution, in Damascus as in all other important centres in the Empire. Among its results worthy of remark here were (a) celebrations and festivities (b) dismissal or resignation oaf notoriously corrupt officials (c) formation of clubs and associations (d) parliamentary elections (e) reforms in various governmental departments. (f) release or rehabilitation of political exiles or persons [xxx].
Rejoicings and joyful manifestation are only coming now to an end, after lasting more than two months: more than 25 well organized great meetings were held int he different quarters of the city, mostly attended by several thousands [sic] demonstrators and spectators, and hundreds of speeches were delivered, all condemning autocracy as despotic & tyrannical and eulogizing liberty and constitutional government. About £2000 were spent on the festivities and had not notables of Damascus with the young Turks lately recommended their cessation they might have continued for another month or more. It is to be remarked with pleasure that all these gathering & demonstrations were conducted most orderly without any dispute or ill feeling among those who assembled.
Many corrupt officials were either dismissed or withdrew themselves.
The Alaybey of Gendarmerie, the Chief of Police, the Muhassebeji, six Caimacams of Cazas, Moh.d P. Adm [Muḥammad Pasha al-ʿAẓm] of Idara Mejliss with about 30 other minor officials vacated their posts, mostly to the general satisfaction of the public and it is debated now among ‘Young Turkey’ adherents whether it would be right to punish the officials who were led to bribery by the littleness of their pay & its frequent irregularity. Doubtless the proper course will be followed in leaving this matter to the jurisdiction
of Parliament when it assembles, and the ignorious[?] dismissal of the more corrupt, rapacious & outrageous among officials suffices for the moment. Moreover, the vacancies are not being easily filled up by really good substitutes, for such persons are at present rare, and often unwilling to serve.
Damascus Clubs & associations, besides the Union & Progress number now five viz Hurriyet, Ulema, Medical, Commercial, Free Ottoman besides a Shoemaker guild. the first two are showing much activity wh.[ich] is likely to excite mutation . The misapprehension & with uncalled solicitude Ulema are anxious to comcure [?sic] & uphold Islam against the liberal views of the Young Turks, while the latter have no intention at present to interfere with religious precepts. The first point of dispute was about women’s wear which the Ulema wanted to be cut on a very simple mode, one piece enveloping the whole body, and the liberals denied them the right of interfering with this matter which should be regarded as pertaining to individual free choice. In this campaign the Ulema were defeated but not without their rivals using threats of applying force.
There is little record as to practical work effected [?] by other clubs though their moral influence cannot be other than good.
The Parliamentary elections are under preparation the last two months and in some cazas the voters have already voted for the electors, but in Damascus city this process will begin in a week’s time. It is not even announced yet how many deputies will represent this Vilayet in the Parliament but it is supposed that they will be seven or eight. The Hauran people still reject their privilege to elect a deputy and the efforts of the government in dissuading them from this self-inflicted loss seem to be futile. The Mutessarif of Kerak lately resigned on grounds of health, but before doing so had been able to set going a local society or club for instruction of the people of his district who indeed are little less backward &ignorant than this of Hauran.
The reforms in the various departments of the government proceed slowly. The Municipality suppressed most improperly awarded pensions paid to persons doing nothing for it and succeeded in amassing about £3000 through various economies. The Public Instruction Department formed a new chamber to consider the reorganization of the educational system in this Vilayet. In the departments no special reforms worth mentioning have been introduced but many are being talked of & discussed.
The political exiles who had been releases or rehabilitated included many persons of rank, both military and civil. Mushir Fuad Pasha’s release was the occasion of great demonstrations in Damascus, but the rehabilitation of others, with a few exceptions, was not publicly noticed, for this disgraces persons were always enjoying personal freedom
and a very few persons knew that they were ‘Ikamet Mamours’ [iqāma maʾmūr]. The chief names among these were, Nouri P. Ferik of Cavalry, another Ferik called Nouri Pasha sent to live here without duties, Ferik Ibrahim Pasha (those three Feriks kept for Constantinople), Ferik Lt. Osman P., Liva Behjet Pasha (those two died recently), Colonel Bedri Bey (now of Liva Bedri P. in Constantinople). The Maàriz Mushiri [?] & his assistant, and many minor officials or private persons; such as members of the Bedr Khan family, numbering more than a hundred. Further as reported in desp. No. 32, the Ismailians subjected to religious persecution were pardoned. Happily no sort of disorder or riotous intention was displayed here for the purpose of releasing prisoners and ordinary criminals generally, as took place in some other places."
Ḥijāz railway was completed in seven years and inaugurated on 1 Sep 1908. four of the five battalions employed for earthworks on the line were allowed to return to their garrisons. "about 1400 of these battalions on expiry of service were disbanded. Moreover, the four battalions of the 40th Reg, sent to Medina from this Army Corps in June last, to guard the line, are also ordered back to their headquarters. At present only two battalions are to be kept there to take care of the line as regards repairs & protection." No aspirations to commence construction beyond Medina due to increasing Bedouin raids
"Public security in the Vilayet has been during the quarter satisfactory and order was properly kept. The Bedouins have been quiet & peaceful during the summer, and only on two or three occasions made petty rais & drove or carried away animals or goods but the spoils were restored to their owners without great difficulties." Druze and Bedouins seem under the spell of the government and calmly wait for the implementation of the promised reforms
"the crops this year were in general very good and the grain harvest in most of the districts of the Province was exceptionally abundant. The apricot produce was above the average while walnuts were much below. All prices of fruit and cereals are still high and the peasants this year will do well. An exception might be mentioned as
as regards locusts which made a perceptible damage in the Kalamoun district but had a very slight effect in some other Cazas. But the loss to the Vilayet in general has been small.
As respects trade, no special remarks need be made; strikes at Beirut at the Customs and on local railways have produced only exiguous loss here. With reference to the latter we may note that public opinion judges that the smaller employés were underpaid, while the profits of the Company & of its directors were considerable and the public at the same time ill served.
Public health has been satisfactory on the whole this summer, but the Ain Fijeh water has not been received the general approbation anticipated which is to be regretted, as theres is absolute proof the it is the best & purest spring water of al this neighbourhood. Its distribution to all quarters of the city proceeds slowly."
Jerusalem, K.Nr. 154 / J. Nr. 2252, 17 Jul 1917, Dr. Brode to Reichskanzler Dr. Michaelis

# Jerusalem, K.Nr. 154 / J. Nr. 2252, 17 Jul 1917, Dr. Brode to Reichskanzler Dr. Michaelis
Im Anschluss an den Bericht vom 28.v.M.J.Nr.1964 K.Nr. 136
"Der Geschäftsführer des jetzt in Liquidation befindlichen Getreidesyndikats, Oberleutnant Dragoman Dr. Grobba [Dr. Fritz Grobba] hat dem kommandierenden General des XXII. Armeekorps Freiherrn von Kress über die diesjährige Ernte- und Verpflegungsaussichten einen Bericht erstatten [sic], dessen Abschrift ich mich beehre Euer Exzellenz zur hochgeneigten Einsicht anliegend zu überreichen.
Was meinen Amtsbezirk bezw. die Etappeninspektion Jerusalem anlangt, so darf ich in folgendem die Ergebnisse dieses Berichts in kurzer Übersicht zusammenfassen. Ich bemerke dabei im Voraus, dass die von Oberleutnant Grobba kritisch verwerteten Zahlen, da auf türkischen Schätzungen beruhend, nicht unbedingt zuverlässig sein können, meines Erachtens jedoch wenigstens in ihren grossen Zügen annähernd richtig sein dürften, sodass sie die allgemeine Lage sowie deren zukünftige Entwicklung mit einiger Sicherheit erkennen lassen.
Wie Euer Exzellenz aus den Vorberichten bekannt ist, hat im Bereich der IV. Armee die Verpflegungsfrage für die Zivilbevölkerung insofern eine endgültige Regelung gefunden als die **Zivil**behörde hiermit beauftragt worden ist. Die oberste Leitung ist jetzt dem Wali von Syrien (d.h. Damaskus) Tahsin Bey übertragen worden, der seinerseits wieder angeordnet hat, dass der Bedarf der Zivilbevölkerung durch die Etappeninspektionen durch (zwangsweisen) Ankauf sicher zu stellen ist. Auf diese Weise soll, wenigstens für einen bedeutenden Teil dieses Bedarfs, die
Fürsorge und die Verantwortung doch wiederum der Militärbehörde - Etappeninspektionen - zufallen.
Der Etappeninspektion Jerusalem unterstehen:
1. _Gänzlich_ d.h. sowohl bezüglich der Erhebung der Zehnten von der Ernte, wie des Verfügunsrechts über die Ernte:
1. Das selbständige Mutessariflik Jerusalem (Kazas: Jerusalem, Jaffa, Hebron, Berseba, Gaza)
2. Aus dem Berzirk der Provinz Syrien (Damaskus) der westliche Teil des Mutessarifliks Kerak (im Ostjordanlande) nämlich der eigentliche Kreis Kerak, der Zentralkreis Salt nebst dem Amtsbezirk Madeba.
Anmerkung: Die Etappeninspektion umfasst demnach nicht den ganzen Teil _meines_ Amtsbezirks, zu dem das ganze Sandjak Kerak gehört.
2. _Zumteil_ d.h. nur bezüglich Erhebung des (dopplten) Zehnten:
+ Von der Provinz Beirut, der Reg.Bezirk Nablus
Das vorraussichtliche Ernteergebnis in meinem Amtsbezirk, von Nablus also abgesehen, ist im eigentlichen Bezirk Jerusalem und im Ostjordanlande verschieden. Zunächst hat sich die Anbaufläche im Bezirk Jerusalem verringert, da ein Teil der Kazas Berseba und Gaza sich in Feindeshand befindet, ferner infloge der militärischen Einziehungen und Requisitionen Arbeitskräfte und Tiere fehlen und weil schliesslich dem Fellachen bei der drückenden Steuerlast und der nicht enden wollenden behördlichen Schikanen jede Lust fehlt, sein Land über seinen eigenen Bedarf hinaus zu bestellen. Beeinträchtigt wird das Ernteergebnis noch durch ungünstige Witterungseinflüsse. Diese Missstände fehlen im Ostjordanland gänzlich, dessen Bewohner im allgemeinen vom Militärdienste befreit sind, ihre Arbeitstiere besser dem militärischen Zugriff entziehen können und
schliesslich [...]
[...] Jerusalem unter
stehenden Gebiete [...]
[...] sei es durch freien
Ankauf [...]
Wird noch ein weiterer Zehnt von jedem Produkt zwangsweise angekauft, wie vorgeschlagen ist, so ermässigt sich der Fehlbetrag auf 1425000 kg Brotgetreide, 1220200 kg Viehfutter und 3093750 kg Trockengemüse. Dieser Fehlbetrag wäre dann wohl, da "freie" Aufkäufe im hiesigen Bezirk mit Rücksicht auf die Bedürfnisse der Zivilbevölkerung schwerlich mehr möglich sein würden, vom Norden her mit der Bahn heranzuschaffen.
Bei diesen geplanten grossen Zwangsankäufen von insgesamt 3/8 der Ernte an Brotgetreide für die Armee bleibt der leidende Teil der Zivilbevölkerung. Ihr täglicher Bedarf ist von Djemal Pascha auf 250 gr Getreide (300 g Brot) festgesetzt worden; in Friedenszeiten verbrauchte der Landeseinwohner täglich 600 - 800 g Brot, so dass die jetzige Rationierung für ihn eine schwer erträgliche Einschränkung bedeutet. Es fragt sich aber, ob die Regierung überhaupt imstande sein wird, der Bevölkerung, die ihr zugemessene Menge verschaffen zu können. Nimmt man die gesamt Bevölkerungszahl der der Etappe Jerusalem unterstehenden Gebiete (Jerusalem, der westliche Teil von Kerak und Nablus) mit 612081 Seelen an - was vielleicht ziemlich genau stimmen könnte - , so würden diese jährlich
(250 g pro Kopf täglich) 55852300 kg Brotgetreide benötigen. Die Gesamternte an Brotgetreide (Weizen und Durra) beträgt aber überhaupt nur 5876800 kg, so dass diese also bei der geplanten knappen Rationierung nur einen geringen Ueberschuss von rund 3 Millionen kg lässt. Nun nimmt aber die Armee vorweg ihren Anteil von entweder 2/8 (nur von Weizen) gleich 10 Millionen kg oder aber vielleicht auch von 3/8 gleich 15 Millionen kg. Für die Zivilbevölkerung würde sich demnach ein Fehlbetrag von 7084301 bis zu 12084300 kg Brotgetreide ergeben.
Dieser Fehlbetrag hat an sich nicht solche erschreckende Bedeutung, wie es auf den ersten Blick wohl erscheinen mag. Allerdings müsste ein etwaiger Ersatz von norden her mit der Eisenbahn herangeschafft werden, die neben ihren bisherigen unzulänglichen Leistungen für die Armeebedürfnisse schwerlich noch 12000t für die Zivilbevölkerung bewältigen könnte. Selbst wenn sie dazu imstand wäre, fragt es sich doch, ob die Ernteergebnisse in den Wilajets Damaskus oder Aleppo derartige sind, dass ein Betrag in dieser Höhe abgegeben werden könnte. Ich möchte es verneinen. Trotz alledem sehe ich aber die Lage nicht zu pessimistisch an; wohlgemerkt nicht etwa im Vertrauen auf eine etwaige gute Organisation und sparsame Wirtschaft - so etwas ist unter türkischer Leitung nun einmal unmöglich -, sondern weil trotz aller Statistik, schliesslich doch eine, wenn auch knapp ausreichende Menge an Lebensmitteln in unserem Besitz vorhanden ist. Jede hier nach einem einheitlichen Gesichtspunkte aufgestellte Statistik hat den Fehler, dass sie ein den Tatsachen nicht entsprechendes gleichmässiges Mass zugrundelegt. Die Bevölkerung lebt ja mit Vorliebe von Brot, wenn es aber nicht reicht, kann sie sich, wenigstens als Zu
satz, der vor dem Verhungern schützt, mit anderen Produkten begnügen, wie Feigen, Kaktusfeigen, Apfelsinen, Weintrauben, Früchten usw. Die Bevölkerung ist ja im Grunde sehr genügsam und des öfteren in ihren grossen Teilen an Hungerperioden gewöhnt. Dazu kommt noch, dass die Verhältnisse in Stadt und Land verschiedenen sind. Gerade die Landbewohner werden Mittel finden, um einigermassen durchzukommen; nur für grössere Städte, vor allem Jerusalem, wird die Frage brennend werden. Hierfür besteht nach meiner Meinung die grösste Besorgnis. Trotz der schwierigen Ankaufs- und Transportverhältnisse - eine Eisenbahnlinie steht ja für die Versorgung Jerusalems aus dem Ostjordenlande nicht zur Verfügung - wäre es aber technisch möglich, auch diese Kalamatität zu bewältigen, wenn man eben nicht mit der geringen Leistungsfähigkeit und der Ungeschicklichkeit der türkischen Etappe rechnen müsste. Da auf dieser, wie bereits angeführt, letzten Endes doch die gesamte Fürsorge für die Verpflegung der Zivilbevölkerung ruht, die Etappe aber aller Voraussicht nach nicht einmal im Stande sein wird, den Heeresbedarf regelmässig zu decken, so wird sie notgedrungen die Zivilbevölkerung hungern lassen müssen. Der Schmuggelhandel wird ja die Leiden etwas mildern, die Wohlhabenderen Bevölkerungsteile werden sich ferner selbst genügend versorgen können. Die grosse Masse der Armen aber dürfte schwere Zeiten erleben. Unter diesen Umständen halte ich es keineswegs für unmöglich, dass man dann gelegentlich türkischerseits wiedereinmal die Frage wenigstens teilweisen Evakuierung von Jerusalem aufrollt.
Die in Liquidation befindliche Getreidekommission hat auch jetzt noch der Regierung ihre Dienste zur Verfügung gestellt und hoffe, mit den ihr zu Transportzwecken über-
lassenen 500 Eseln monatlich 125000 kg Getreide heranschaffen zu können. Dies würde ungefähr etwas mehr als der vierte Teil des monatlichen Bedarfs sein (250 g täglich für etwa 53000 Seelen). Die Getreidekommission wird daher zunächst, um wenigstens etwas vollkommen zu erreichen, den Bedarf der Wohltätigkeitsanstalten und bestimmter Bevölkerungsteile, darunter auch die deutsche Kolonie, gänzlich decken. Die Vorarbeiten hierzu sind im Gange.
Wie die Sache sich nun weiter entwickeln wird bleibt abzuwarten."
Dr. Brode
- 3 copies attached. The report and the attachments are also sent to the embassy and the consular agents in Constantinople, Beirut, Aleppo, Damascus. The attachment is also sent to the command of the 22. Army Corps.
PRO FO 618/3 Damascus Draft 42, Quarterly Report, Mishāqa to Marling 10 Jul. 1913

no administrative changes in Hama and Ḥawrān
Kerak
: "a whole flock of sheep to the number of about 5,000 + 42 camels were robbed by Bedouins, property belonging to British Indian Merchants"
Shawqī Bey, from the istiʾnāf court, and Ismāʿīl Ḥaqqī Bey, the judicial inspector, returned from their tour of insepction to Hama and Homs and went to Ḥawrān and Kerak
Several members of the courts in Damascus "have been either dismissed or degraded being found guilty of bribery +
corruption, but I regret to say that those who have been replaced them are of no better character, corruption + bribery is still going on a large scale in the diff. courts.
The desultory talk about decentralization has been hushed up temporarily on account of the outrages occurring at Consple. + the severe capital punishment inflicted on several persons of high social standing, concerned in the murder of the Grand Ministre Shuskat Pasha.
Previous however to the above mentioned incidents a meeting was held in the house of the ex-deputy Abdur Rahman
Abdu Ruhma Bey el Yussuf, composed chiefly of the Union + Progress Party. A telegram was sent by this Party to the murdered Grand Vizir controversing Reforms demanded by the Union + Liberty Party (Titilafiyin) at Paris. The telegram has Many of the signatures turned to be falsely signed without the knowledge of their owners.
The Local Press here and at Beirut opened a voley of a severe criticism and exposed the ex-deputy's name blaming and attacking him for a speech he delivered on the occasion in which he insulted in low terms persons of high standing + good reputation from
the Union + Liberty Party, such as the ex-deputy Shukri Bey Asali and Abdul Wahab Eff. Inglisy, who in their turn convoked a meeting and a telegram was sent on behalf of the Damascene people in general endorsing the reforms demanded by the Paris Party tho that first tel sent by the Paris Party and and dementing a telegram was the second sent by the Union + Liberty Progress Party at Damascus. However the idea of decentralization has been as above referred hushed up for the time being but it is more likely to reappear in a more vigorous form.
The Sanitary Dept. + Private Doctors report bad Public health during the quarter; Scarletine fever is now at an end but was for about two months derrating nearly
months an epidemic in this district + in its surroundings. At Baalbek it is reported that hardly any house escaped the visit by this disease. Death however did not exceed 7 to 8 %.
Small pox made its appearance first in the Hauran district and then here. But the Sanitary Dept. has taken the usual necessary measures by vaccination to fight it which is now disappearing. Several fatal cases of typhoid fever have been reported and it still exists in different quarters of the town.
Among the high officials removed may be mentioned H.E. the General Suleiman Faik Pasha, of the VIII Army Corps, order from the Ministry of War at Consple. reached this quarter
while he was on an inspection tour at Homs + Palmyra. H.E. left soon after his arrival to Damascus and his place has been occupied by H.E. the Cpt. Moh.d Shefik Pasha. It is alleged that the removal of ex-general is due to the instigation of the ex-1st Etat Major (Nouri Bey) […] His removal nevertheless has been much regretted on account of his kind and gentle character.
On the 22nd of May two insubordinate Rediff infantry battalions to the number of about 700 arrived from Yemen, they behaved badly in the town and on
one occasion policemen at Souk Ali Pasha who trying to arrest one of them on acc.t of drunkness + ill behaviour was badly handled by them, and they succeeded in getting their like ration. This incident insubordination having ended in success encouraged the Rediff battalion infantry of Nebk to the number of about 150 men to fully ar to make a mutiny: Fully armed they proceeded to the Big Omiades Mosque and disobeyed orders, demanding also their liberation (Tizkarahs), H.E. The ex-General + the Vali blocked up the Mosque by gendarmes + Policemen and decided to famish out the revolting soldiers and sever measures were to be taken but a telegraphic order was received from Consple to the Ministry of War at Consple to grant
them their liberation. Thus Badr eddin Bey (Nakib el Ashraf) with several other Ulamas were sent to the Mosque who preached the revolted soldiers were asked to yield and their liberation was guaranteed which indeed was given to them in the same day. This incident of Sleakness on the Part of the Mil. Auth. made a very bad impression on the native people here who are loosing faith in the Gov.t Power. This incident will undoubtedly encourage others whenever opportunity is presented.
The season product proved very good. Fruits are very abundant especially apricots. The coming season however is not very promising for cereals as rain was quite short at the end.
"
Admin changes: in the districts.
- the chief of police in Damascus, Amīn Bey, was removed to Beirut and replaced with the Damascene Muḥammad Efendi Qudmānī
- most members of the penal division of the istiʾnāf court have been dismissed; providing all the names

PRO FO 371/560 (44/F.37953/08) Baghdad, Major Ramsay to Government of India 21 Sep. 1908

(44/F37953/08)
Therapia 721, 27 Oct 1908, Lowther
“Wheat Riots at Baghdad, Major Bemsay’s No 864 reporting on”
Enclosing the despatch by the Consul General in Baghdad

#Inclosure no. 1
Bagdad, 21 Sep 1908, Major Ramsay to Government of India
“Sir,
In continuation of my letter [No. 847] dated the 14th instant, I have the honour to report that the telegram of which the purport was given in the third paragraph of that letter appears to have been malevolently added to in Bagdad before it was made partially public. The original telegram, as received from Constantinople, contained no reference to the use of military force against the Young Turk Committee in provincial towns. The perverted version of the telegram was made known in Karbala.
2. On the 16th instant there was a riot in which some of the grain stored were pillaged. The exportation of wheat has for some time been prohibited, and on the 14th and 15th instant it was rumoured that a certain Jew had received permission from Constantinople to export some wheat and that he was going to load it on the 16th. On that morning a crowd went to the Vali to protest. It is said that the Vali assured them that no order had been issued allowing the export of wheat, and it is said that the Vali strengthened his assurance by saying that when an attempt to load wad made it would time for the people to make serious complaints. It is not possible to know exactly what was said, much less what was understood, but the crowd went straight off to the grain stores and took what they could carry. It was at first reported that the loss was enormous, but the estimates have since been largely reduced, and I am inclined to think that the loss cannot have been very great. The populace took what it could during an interval of about an hour and a-half, but the entrances to the store are narrow and they were choked by the crowd, so much so that a number of the rioters found it convenient to pass their stolen wheat over the wall. In these circumstances a very large quantity of wheat cannot have been removed. Messrs. Lynch’s experience is that with the best arrangement, and all wheat in bags, not more than 100 tons could be removed in an hour and a-half. A very small proportion of this can have been taken by a struggling crowd.
One man claimed compensation for about 600l. [£ 600] worth of wheat which he said he held on behalf of a British subject and which he said had been pillaged during the riot. I went to his place of business to examine his books, and he then said that he did not want the intervention of the Consulate and would settle the matter himself.
Another man who claimed compensation on behalf of Messrs. Andrew Weir and Co. of London had to admit that he could not produce proof that any Court would accept.
A third man’s claim is still under consideration, but from what I have heard I am pretty fairly certain that it will not stand examination.
There is no doubt that all of these men have lost wheat, but they cannot prove that it was the property of British subjects.
3. There are a number of deserters about Bagdad who are a continual source of <pb/> danger to peaceful people. I understand that the Commander of the VIth Army Corps has written to Constantinople to say that it is necessary either to come to some settlement with them or to shoot them.
4. The Young Turk Committee at Karbala has made all the officials publicly swear loyalty to the Constitution, but the Mutessarif shows a strong dislike to interference, and the Vali of Bagdad is said to be troubled with many differences between the two parties.

I have, &c. …
